critique: This executive order, issued by George Bush in 1991, focuses on waste reduction and recycling within the federal government. It mandates federal agencies to promote cost-effective waste reduction and recycling programs, encourages the purchase of recycled materials, and establishes a council to coordinate these efforts. The order aims to conserve resources, reduce pollution, and promote environmentally sound practices. It does not directly address immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. It also does not seem to expand executive power significantly, as it primarily directs internal management within the executive branch. The order promotes federal action and coordination, suggesting a slight leaning towards federal primacy. It also involves government intervention in promoting recycling and procurement practices, indicating a move towards economic regulation. Finally, it does not directly address ideological tilt.
